name: Islamic Center of Southern California
mission: The Islamic Center is more than a place of worship. We are a community united in pursuing spiritual growth, compassion, and knowledge. Our mission is to provide a welcoming and inclusive environment where people can come together to connect, learn, and give back.
zakatClaimEvidence: The Islamic Center of Southern California (ICSC) explicitly mentions "Zakat & Sadaqah – Fulfill your religious obligations and assist those in need within our community" under its 'Ways to Give' section. Furthermore, it has a dedicated 'Zakat Program' that "offers crucial support including $15 food coupons, rental assistance, and utility assistance to help alleviate immediate needs". The ICSC's donation page also lists "Zakat al-Fitr" and "Zakat al-Mal" as specific donation categories. (Source: https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQEcbVWaxZpWjtyTy3jiV-1Vr_Lsq_ady9PujulHZYifVGezgk7GN3_arJjtKi2PZ-5JA47WELsJs_Mgs_pI_CXEE1jdpwsf5WDtPjREJhkd2VRo23SbtiHpv7B0)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Limited match due to weaker results and/or higher uncertainty; review methodology details before deciding.

components.evidence: Accepts zakat (+2); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1); Asnaf: fi_sabilillah (+5)
components.improvement_suggestion: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

components.improvement_suggestion: Expand services to underserved populations or geographies with limited nonprofit coverage.
components.name: Underserved Space

alignment.rationale: Alignment 25/50: MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, religious cultural cause area

components.improvement_suggestion: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: If reserves are above policy target, document why and publish triggers for planned deployment.
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes over at least 3 years.
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

components.improvement_suggestion: Document a clear theory of change with an explicit causal pathway.
components.name: Theory of Change

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Program expense ratio critically low: 50%

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Islamic Center of Southern California shows moderate alignment and limited impact, with zakat compliance (significant risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: The Islamic Center of Southern California (ICSC) explicitly mentions "Zakat & Sadaqah – Fulfill your religious obligations and assist those in need within our community" under its 'Ways to Give' section. Furthermore, it has a dedicated 'Zakat Program' that "offers crucial support including $15 food coupons, rental assistance, and utility assistance to help alleviate immediate needs". The ICSC's donation page also lists "Zakat al-Fitr" and "Zakat al-Mal" as specific donation categories. (Source: https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQEcbVWaxZpWjtyTy3jiV-1Vr_Lsq_ady9PujulHZYifVGezgk7GN3_arJjtKi2PZ-5JA47WELsJs_Mgs_pI_CXEE1jdpwsf5WDtPjREJhkd2VRo23SbtiHpv7B0)

all_citations.claim: The organization's financial metadata and profile information are tracked by industry evaluators.
The Islamic Center of Southern California reported total revenue of $2,134,893 and a program expense ratio of 49.6%.
The center operates as an independent organization providing food pantry, Sunday school, and funeral services.
The organization accepts donations and is identified as Zakat-eligible.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization receives a score of 33/100, reflecting a balance between strong financial liquidity and a need for greater transparency regarding program spending and impact evidence.
areas_for_improvement: program expense ratio of 49.6% is lower than industry benchmarks for direct service delivery
Limited external data availability regarding specific program outcomes and impact metrics

dimension_explanations.alignment: With an alignment score of 25/50, the organization shows a medium fit for donors interested in religious and cultural preservation, supported by its Zakat-eligible status and long-standing presence in Southern California [3][4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The center demonstrates a capacity-building model through its food pantry and educational services, though its impact score of 15/50 is limited by a program expense ratio of 49.6% and a lack of third-party verified outcome data [1][2][3].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Islamic Center of Southern California serves as an independent pillar for the Muslim community, providing essential religious, educational, and social services.
strengths: Maintains a robust liquidity position with 17.2 months of working capital
High fundraising efficiency with a cost of $0.00 per $1 raised
Offers diverse community programs including a food pantry, Sunday school, and funeral services
baseline_narrative.summary: The Islamic Center of Southern California is an independent organization dedicated to practicing and sharing Islamic values through community-focused programs [3]. In the 2023 fiscal year, the center reported a total revenue of $2,134,893 to support its mission and diverse service offerings [2].
